projectDesc.p: This version of the Folger Digital Texts uses TEI Simple to encode the Shakespeare texts edited by Barbara Mowat and Paul Werstine. The major goal of recasting the texts in this manner is to make them interoperable with a large corpus of early modern texts derived from the EEBO-TCP transcriptions and encoded in TEI Simple with linguistic annotation.

For a full description of the encoding practices of the Folger Digital Texts consult their encodingDesc section. This version is completely faithful to the readings, orthogrgraphy, and punctuation of the source text. It uses a different XML encoding scheme, with occasional losses in expressiveness. The major differences are:
Number div are replaced by unnumbered divs
Lines of verse are marked in l, tags, lines of prose in ab
All xml:ids are corpuswide identifiers
Information from the participant description element particDesc in the teiHeader has been moved into a castList element in the front element
Each spoken word in the text has been linguistically annotated with a lemma and POS tag

refsDecl.p: Words, spaces, and punctuation characters are numbered sequentially, incremented by 10.

Most other elements begin with an element-specific prefix, followed by a reference to the Folger Through Line Number, a sequential numbering of the numbered lines in the text. If an element is inline with play text, it has the same line number as the line where it begins. If it begins on a line following play text, a decimal number is appended and incremented as necessary. If it falls between a speech prefix and the play text, a ".0" is appended to the value of the following line number.

castGroup.head: Attendants, Maskers, Torchbearers, a Boy with a drum, Gentlemen, Gentlewomen, Tybalt’s Page, Servingmen.

sp.l: Two households, both alike in dignity
( In fair Verona, where we lay our scene),
From ancient grudge break to new mutiny,
Where civil blood makes civil hands unclean.
From forth the fatal loins of these two foes
A pair of star-crossed lovers take their life;
Whose misadventured piteous overthrows
Doth with their death bury their parents’ strife.
The fearful passage of their death-marked love
And the continuance of their parents’ rage,
Which, but their children’s end, naught could remove,
Is now the two hours’ traffic of our stage;
The which, if you with patient ears attend,
What here shall miss, our toil shall strive to mend.

div.head: Scene 1
div.stage: Enter Sampson and Gregory, with swords and bucklers, of the house of Capulet.

sp.speaker: SAMPSON
sp.p: Gregory, on my word we’ll not carry coals.

sp.speaker: GREGORY
sp.p: No, for then we should be colliers.

sp.speaker: SAMPSON
sp.p: I mean, an we be in choler, we’ll draw.

sp.speaker: GREGORY
sp.p:
Ay, while you live, draw your neck out of
collar.

sp.speaker: SAMPSON
sp.p: I strike quickly, being moved.

sp.speaker: GREGORY
sp.p: But thou art not quickly moved to strike.

sp.speaker: SAMPSON
sp.p: A dog of the house of Montague moves me.

sp.speaker: GREGORY
sp.p:
To move is to stir, and to be valiant is to
stand. Therefore if thou art moved thou runn’st
away.

sp.speaker: SAMPSON
sp.p:
A dog of that house shall move me to stand. I
will take the wall of any man or maid of Montague’s.

sp.speaker: GREGORY
sp.p:
That shows thee a weak slave, for the weakest
goes to the wall.

sp.speaker: SAMPSON
sp.p:
’Tis true, and therefore women, being the
weaker vessels, are ever thrust to the wall. Therefore
I will push Montague’s men from the wall and
thrust his maids to the wall.

sp.speaker: GREGORY
sp.p:
The quarrel is between our masters and us
their men.

sp.speaker: SAMPSON
sp.p:
’Tis all one. I will show myself a tyrant.
When I have fought with the men, I will be civil
with the maids; I will cut off their heads.

sp.speaker: GREGORY
sp.p: The heads of the maids?

sp.speaker: SAMPSON
sp.p:
Ay, the heads of the maids, or their maidenheads.
Take it in what sense thou wilt.

sp.speaker: GREGORY
sp.p: They must take it in sense that feel it.

sp.speaker: SAMPSON
sp.p:
Me they shall feel while I am able to stand,
and ’tis known I am a pretty piece of flesh.

sp.speaker: GREGORY
sp.p:
’Tis well thou art not fish; if thou hadst, thou
hadst been poor-john. Draw thy tool. Here comes
of the house of Montagues.

sp.speaker: SAMPSON
sp.p:
My naked weapon is out. Quarrel, I will back
thee.

sp.speaker: GREGORY
sp.p: How? Turn thy back and run?

sp.speaker: SAMPSON
sp.p: Fear me not.

sp.speaker: GREGORY
sp.p: No, marry. I fear thee!

sp.speaker: SAMPSON
sp.p:
Let us take the law of our sides; let them
begin.

sp.speaker: GREGORY
sp.p:
I will frown as I pass by, and let them take it
as they list.

sp.speaker: SAMPSON
sp.p:
Nay, as they dare. I will bite my thumb at
them, which is disgrace to them if they bear it.

sp.speaker: ABRAM
sp.p: Do you bite your thumb at us, sir?

sp.speaker: SAMPSON
sp.p: I do bite my thumb, sir.

sp.speaker: ABRAM
sp.p: Do you bite your thumb at us, sir?

sp.speaker: SAMPSON
sp.p:
Is the law of our side if I
say “ Ay”?

sp.speaker: GREGORY
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: SAMPSON
sp.p:
No, sir, I do not bite my thumb at you, sir,
but I bite my thumb, sir.

sp.speaker: GREGORY
sp.p: Do you quarrel, sir?

sp.speaker: ABRAM
sp.p: Quarrel, sir? No, sir.

sp.speaker: SAMPSON
sp.p:
But if you do, sir, I am for you. I serve as
good a man as you.

sp.speaker: ABRAM
sp.p: No better.

sp.speaker: SAMPSON
sp.p: Well, sir.

sp.speaker: GREGORY
sp.p:
Say “ better”; here comes
one of my master’s kinsmen.

sp.speaker: SAMPSON
sp.p: Yes, better, sir.

sp.speaker: ABRAM
sp.p: You lie.

sp.speaker: SAMPSON
sp.p:
Draw if you be men.— Gregory, remember
thy washing blow.

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.p: Part, fools!
sp.l: Put up your swords. You know not what you do.

sp.speaker: TYBALT
sp.l: What, art thou drawn among these heartless hinds?
Turn thee, Benvolio; look upon thy death.

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: I do but keep the peace. Put up thy sword,
Or manage it to part these men with me.

sp.speaker: TYBALT
sp.l: What, drawn and talk of peace? I hate the word
As I hate hell, all Montagues, and thee.
Have at thee, coward!

div.stage: Enter three or four Citizens with clubs or partisans.

sp.speaker: CITIZENS
sp.l: Clubs, bills, and partisans! Strike! Beat them down!
Down with the Capulets! Down with the Montagues!

div.stage: Enter old Capulet in his gown, and his Wife.

sp.speaker: CAPULET
sp.l: What noise is this? Give me my long sword, ho!

sp.speaker: LADY CAPULET
sp.l: A crutch, a crutch! Why call you for a sword?

div.stage: Enter old Montague and his Wife.

sp.speaker: CAPULET
sp.l: My sword, I say. Old Montague is come
And flourishes his blade in spite of me.

sp.speaker: MONTAGUE
sp.l: Thou villain Capulet!— Hold me not; let me go.

sp.speaker: LADY MONTAGUE
sp.l: Thou shalt not stir one foot to seek a foe.

div.stage: Enter Prince Escalus with his train.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.l: Rebellious subjects, enemies to peace,
Profaners of this neighbor-stainèd steel—
Will they not hear?— What ho! You men, you beasts,
That quench the fire of your pernicious rage
With purple fountains issuing from your veins:
On pain of torture, from those bloody hands
Throw your mistempered weapons to the ground,
And hear the sentence of your movèd prince.
Three civil brawls bred of an airy word
By thee, old Capulet, and Montague,
Have thrice disturbed the quiet of our streets
And made Verona’s ancient citizens
Cast by their grave-beseeming ornaments
To wield old partisans in hands as old,
Cankered with peace, to part your cankered hate.
If ever you disturb our streets again,
Your lives shall pay the forfeit of the peace.
For this time all the rest depart away.
You, Capulet, shall go along with me,
And, Montague, come you this afternoon
To know our farther pleasure in this case,
To old Free-town, our common judgment-place.
Once more, on pain of death, all men depart.

div.stage: All but Montague, Lady Montague, and Benvolio exit.

sp.speaker: MONTAGUE
sp.l: Who set this ancient quarrel new abroach?
Speak, nephew, were you by when it began?

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: Here were the servants of your adversary,
And yours, close fighting ere I did approach.
I drew to part them. In the instant came
The fiery Tybalt with his sword prepared,
Which, as he breathed defiance to my ears,
He swung about his head and cut the winds,
Who, nothing hurt withal, hissed him in scorn.
While we were interchanging thrusts and blows
Came more and more and fought on part and part,
Till the Prince came, who parted either part.

sp.speaker: LADY MONTAGUE
sp.l: O, where is Romeo? Saw you him today?
Right glad I am he was not at this fray.

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: Madam, an hour before the worshiped sun
Peered forth the golden window of the east,
A troubled mind drove me to walk abroad,
Where underneath the grove of sycamore
That westward rooteth from this city side,
So early walking did I see your son.
Towards him I made, but he was ’ware of me
And stole into the covert of the wood.
I, measuring his affections by my own
( Which then most sought where most might not be found,
Being one too many by my weary self),
Pursued my humor, not pursuing his,
And gladly shunned who gladly fled from me.

sp.speaker: MONTAGUE
sp.l: Many a morning hath he there been seen,
With tears augmenting the fresh morning’s dew,
Adding to clouds more clouds with his deep sighs.
But all so soon as the all-cheering sun
Should in the farthest east begin to draw
The shady curtains from Aurora’s bed,
Away from light steals home my heavy son
And private in his chamber pens himself,
Shuts up his windows, locks fair daylight out,
And makes himself an artificial night.
Black and portentous must this humor prove,
Unless good counsel may the cause remove.

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: My noble uncle, do you know the cause?

sp.speaker: MONTAGUE
sp.l: I neither know it nor can learn of him.

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: Have you importuned him by any means?

sp.speaker: MONTAGUE
sp.l: Both by myself and many other friends.
But he, his own affections’ counselor,
Is to himself— I will not say how true,
But to himself so secret and so close,
So far from sounding and discovery,
As is the bud bit with an envious worm
Ere he can spread his sweet leaves to the air
Or dedicate his beauty to the same.
Could we but learn from whence his sorrows grow,
We would as willingly give cure as know.

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: See where he comes. So please you, step aside.
I’ll know his grievance or be much denied.

sp.speaker: MONTAGUE
sp.l: I would thou wert so happy by thy stay
To hear true shrift.— Come, madam, let’s away.

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: Good morrow, cousin.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Is the day so young?

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: But new struck nine.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Ay me, sad hours seem long.
Was that my father that went hence so fast?

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: It was. What sadness lengthens Romeo’s hours?

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Not having that which, having, makes them short.

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.p: In love?

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.p: Out—

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.p: Of love?

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Out of her favor where I am in love.

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: Alas that love, so gentle in his view,
Should be so tyrannous and rough in proof!

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Alas that love, whose view is muffled still,
Should without eyes see pathways to his will!
Where shall we dine?— O me! What fray was here?
Yet tell me not, for I have heard it all.
Here’s much to do with hate, but more with love.
Why then, O brawling love, O loving hate,
O anything of nothing first create!
O heavy lightness, serious vanity,
Misshapen chaos of well-seeming forms,
Feather of lead, bright smoke, cold fire, sick health,
Still-waking sleep that is not what it is!
This love feel I, that feel no love in this.
Dost thou not laugh?

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: No, coz, I rather weep.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Good heart, at what?

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: At thy good heart’s oppression.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Why, such is love’s transgression.
Griefs of mine own lie heavy in my breast,
Which thou wilt propagate to have it pressed
With more of thine. This love that thou hast shown
Doth add more grief to too much of mine own.
Love is a smoke made with the fume of sighs;
Being purged, a fire sparkling in lovers’ eyes;
Being vexed, a sea nourished with loving tears.
What is it else? A madness most discreet,
A choking gall, and a preserving sweet.
Farewell, my coz.

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: Soft, I will go along.
An if you leave me so, you do me wrong.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Tut, I have lost myself. I am not here.
This is not Romeo. He’s some other where.

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: Tell me in sadness, who is that you love?

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: What, shall I groan and tell thee?

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: Groan? Why, no. But sadly tell me who.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: A sick man in sadness makes his will—
A word ill urged to one that is so ill.
In sadness, cousin, I do love a woman.

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: I aimed so near when I supposed you loved.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: A right good markman! And she’s fair I love.

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: A right fair mark, fair coz, is soonest hit.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Well in that hit you miss. She’ll not be hit
With Cupid’s arrow. She hath Dian’s wit,
And, in strong proof of chastity well armed,
From love’s weak childish bow she lives uncharmed.
She will not stay the siege of loving terms,
Nor bide th’ encounter of assailing eyes,
Nor ope her lap to saint-seducing gold.
O, she is rich in beauty, only poor
That, when she dies, with beauty dies her store.

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: Then she hath sworn that she will still live chaste?

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: She hath, and in that sparing makes huge waste;
For beauty, starved with her severity,
Cuts beauty off from all posterity.
She is too fair, too wise, wisely too fair,
To merit bliss by making me despair.
She hath forsworn to love, and in that vow
Do I live dead, that live to tell it now.

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: Be ruled by me. Forget to think of her.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: O, teach me how I should forget to think!

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: By giving liberty unto thine eyes.
Examine other beauties.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: ’Tis the way
To call hers, exquisite, in question more.
These happy masks that kiss fair ladies’ brows,
Being black, puts us in mind they hide the fair.
He that is strucken blind cannot forget
The precious treasure of his eyesight lost.
Show me a mistress that is passing fair;
What doth her beauty serve but as a note
Where I may read who passed that passing fair?
Farewell. Thou canst not teach me to forget.

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: I’ll pay that doctrine or else die in debt.

div.head: Scene 2
div.stage: Enter Capulet, County Paris, and a Servingman.

sp.speaker: CAPULET
sp.l: But Montague is bound as well as I,
In penalty alike, and ’tis not hard, I think,
For men so old as we to keep the peace.

sp.speaker: PARIS
sp.l: Of honorable reckoning are you both,
And pity ’tis you lived at odds so long.
But now, my lord, what say you to my suit?

sp.speaker: CAPULET
sp.l: But saying o’er what I have said before.
My child is yet a stranger in the world.
She hath not seen the change of fourteen years.
Let two more summers wither in their pride
Ere we may think her ripe to be a bride.

sp.speaker: PARIS
sp.l: Younger than she are happy mothers made.

sp.speaker: CAPULET
sp.l: And too soon marred are those so early made.
Earth hath swallowed all my hopes but she;
She’s the hopeful lady of my earth.
But woo her, gentle Paris, get her heart;
My will to her consent is but a part.
And, she agreed, within her scope of choice
Lies my consent and fair according voice.
This night I hold an old accustomed feast,
Whereto I have invited many a guest
Such as I love; and you among the store,
One more, most welcome, makes my number more.
At my poor house look to behold this night
Earth-treading stars that make dark heaven light.
Such comfort as do lusty young men feel
When well-appareled April on the heel
Of limping winter treads, even such delight
Among fresh fennel buds shall you this night
Inherit at my house. Hear all, all see,
And like her most whose merit most shall be;
Which, on more view of many, mine, being one,
May stand in number, though in reck’ning none.
Come go with me.
sp.stage: To Servingman, giving him a list.
sp.l: Go, sirrah, trudge about
Through fair Verona, find those persons out
Whose names are written there, and to them say
My house and welcome on their pleasure stay.

sp.speaker: SERVINGMAN
sp.p:
Find them out whose names are written
here! It is written that the shoemaker should
meddle with his yard and the tailor with his last, the
fisher with his pencil and the painter with his nets.
But I am sent to find those persons whose names
are here writ, and can never find what names the
writing person hath here writ. I must to the learned.
In good time!

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: Tut, man, one fire burns out another’s burning;
One pain is lessened by another’s anguish.
Turn giddy, and be helped by backward turning.
One desperate grief cures with another’s languish.
Take thou some new infection to thy eye,
And the rank poison of the old will die.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Your plantain leaf is excellent for that.

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: For what, I pray thee?

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: For your broken shin.

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: Why Romeo, art thou mad?

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Not mad, but bound more than a madman is,
Shut up in prison, kept without my food,
Whipped and tormented, and— good e’en, good fellow.

sp.speaker: SERVINGMAN
sp.p:
God gi’ good e’en. I pray, sir, can you
read?

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Ay, mine own fortune in my misery.

sp.speaker: SERVINGMAN
sp.p:
Perhaps you have learned it without
book. But I pray, can you read anything you see?

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Ay, if I know the letters and the language.

sp.speaker: SERVINGMAN
sp.p: You say honestly. Rest you merry.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.p: Stay, fellow. I can read.
sp.q:
Signior Martino and his wife and daughters,
County Anselme and his beauteous sisters,
The lady widow of Vitruvio,
Signior Placentio and his lovely nieces,
Mercutio and his brother Valentine,
Mine Uncle Capulet, his wife and daughters,
My fair niece Rosaline and Livia,
Signior Valentio and his cousin Tybalt,
Lucio and the lively Helena.
sp.l: A fair assembly. Whither should they come?

sp.speaker: SERVINGMAN
sp.p: Up.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.p: Whither? To supper?

sp.speaker: SERVINGMAN
sp.p: To our house.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.p: Whose house?

sp.speaker: SERVINGMAN
sp.p: My master’s.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Indeed I should have asked thee that before.

sp.speaker: SERVINGMAN
sp.p:
Now I’ll tell you without asking. My
master is the great rich Capulet, and, if you be not
of the house of Montagues, I pray come and crush a
cup of wine. Rest you merry.

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: At this same ancient feast of Capulet’s
Sups the fair Rosaline whom thou so loves,
With all the admirèd beauties of Verona.
Go thither, and with unattainted eye
Compare her face with some that I shall show,
And I will make thee think thy swan a crow.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: When the devout religion of mine eye
Maintains such falsehood, then turn tears to fire;
And these who, often drowned, could never die,
Transparent heretics, be burnt for liars.
One fairer than my love? The all-seeing sun
Ne’er saw her match since first the world begun.

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: Tut, you saw her fair, none else being by,
Herself poised with herself in either eye;
But in that crystal scales let there be weighed
Your lady’s love against some other maid
That I will show you shining at this feast,
And she shall scant show well that now seems best.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: I’ll go along, no such sight to be shown,
But to rejoice in splendor of mine own.

sp.speaker: LADY CAPULET
sp.l: Nurse, where’s my daughter? Call her forth to me.

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.l: Now, by my maidenhead at twelve year old,
I bade her come.— What, lamb! What, ladybird!
God forbid. Where’s this girl? What, Juliet!

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.p: How now, who calls?

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: Your mother.

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: Madam, I am here. What is your will?

sp.speaker: LADY CAPULET
sp.l: This is the matter.— Nurse, give leave awhile.
We must talk in secret.— Nurse, come back again.
I have remembered me, thou ’s hear our counsel.
Thou knowest my daughter’s of a pretty age.

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.l: Faith, I can tell her age unto an hour.

sp.speaker: LADY CAPULET
sp.p: She’s not fourteen.

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p:
I’ll lay fourteen of my teeth ( and yet, to my teen
be it spoken, I have but four) she’s not fourteen.
How long is it now to Lammastide?

sp.speaker: LADY CAPULET
sp.p: A fortnight and odd days.

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.l: Even or odd, of all days in the year,
Come Lammas Eve at night shall she be fourteen.
Susan and she ( God rest all Christian souls!)
Were of an age. Well, Susan is with God;
She was too good for me. But, as I said,
On Lammas Eve at night shall she be fourteen.
That shall she. Marry, I remember it well.
’Tis since the earthquake now eleven years,
And she was weaned ( I never shall forget it)
Of all the days of the year, upon that day.
For I had then laid wormwood to my dug,
Sitting in the sun under the dovehouse wall.
My lord and you were then at Mantua.
Nay, I do bear a brain. But, as I said,
When it did taste the wormwood on the nipple
Of my dug and felt it bitter, pretty fool,
To see it tetchy and fall out with the dug.
“ Shake,” quoth the dovehouse. ’Twas no need, I trow,
To bid me trudge.
And since that time it is eleven years.
For then she could stand high-lone. Nay, by th’ rood,
She could have run and waddled all about,
For even the day before, she broke her brow,
And then my husband ( God be with his soul,
He was a merry man) took up the child.
“ Yea,” quoth he, “ Dost thou fall upon thy face?
Thou wilt fall backward when thou hast more wit,
Wilt thou not, Jule?” And, by my holidam,
The pretty wretch left crying and said “ Ay.”
To see now how a jest shall come about!
I warrant, an I should live a thousand years,
I never should forget it. “ Wilt thou not, Jule?” quoth he.
And, pretty fool, it stinted and said “ Ay.”

sp.speaker: LADY CAPULET
sp.l: Enough of this. I pray thee, hold thy peace.

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.l: Yes, madam, yet I cannot choose but laugh
To think it should leave crying and say “ Ay.”
And yet, I warrant, it had upon its brow
A bump as big as a young cock’rel’s stone,
A perilous knock, and it cried bitterly.
“ Yea,” quoth my husband. “ Fall’st upon thy face?
Thou wilt fall backward when thou comest to age,
Wilt thou not, Jule?” It stinted and said “ Ay.”

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: And stint thou, too, I pray thee, nurse, say I.

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.l: Peace. I have done. God mark thee to his grace,
Thou wast the prettiest babe that e’er I nursed.
An I might live to see thee married once,
I have my wish.

sp.speaker: LADY CAPULET
sp.l: Marry, that “ marry” is the very theme
I came to talk of.— Tell me, daughter Juliet,
How stands your disposition to be married?

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: It is an honor that I dream not of.

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.l: An honor? Were not I thine only nurse,
I would say thou hadst sucked wisdom from thy teat.

sp.speaker: LADY CAPULET
sp.l: Well, think of marriage now. Younger than you
Here in Verona, ladies of esteem,
Are made already mothers. By my count
I was your mother much upon these years
That you are now a maid. Thus, then, in brief:
The valiant Paris seeks you for his love.

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.l: A man, young lady— lady, such a man
As all the world— why, he’s a man of wax.

sp.speaker: LADY CAPULET
sp.l: Verona’s summer hath not such a flower.

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.l: Nay, he’s a flower, in faith, a very flower.

sp.speaker: LADY CAPULET
sp.l: What say you? Can you love the gentleman?
This night you shall behold him at our feast.
Read o’er the volume of young Paris’ face,
And find delight writ there with beauty’s pen.
Examine every married lineament
And see how one another lends content,
And what obscured in this fair volume lies
Find written in the margent of his eyes.
This precious book of love, this unbound lover,
To beautify him only lacks a cover.
The fish lives in the sea, and ’tis much pride
For fair without the fair within to hide.
That book in many’s eyes doth share the glory
That in gold clasps locks in the golden story.
So shall you share all that he doth possess
By having him, making yourself no less.

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.l: No less? Nay, bigger. Women grow by men.

sp.speaker: LADY CAPULET
sp.l: Speak briefly. Can you like of Paris’ love?

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: I’ll look to like, if looking liking move.
But no more deep will I endart mine eye
Than your consent gives strength to make it fly.

sp.speaker: SERVINGMAN
sp.p:
Madam, the guests are come, supper
served up, you called, my young lady asked for, the
Nurse cursed in the pantry, and everything in
extremity. I must hence to wait. I beseech you,
follow straight.

sp.speaker: LADY CAPULET
sp.l: We follow thee.
Juliet, the County stays.

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.l: Go, girl, seek happy nights to happy days.

div.head: Scene 4
div.stage: Enter Romeo, Mercutio, Benvolio, with five or six other Maskers, Torchbearers, and a Boy with a drum.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: What, shall this speech be spoke for our excuse?
Or shall we on without apology?

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: The date is out of such prolixity.
We’ll have no Cupid hoodwinked with a scarf,
Bearing a Tartar’s painted bow of lath,
Scaring the ladies like a crowkeeper,
Nor no without-book prologue, faintly spoke
After the prompter, for our entrance.
But let them measure us by what they will.
We’ll measure them a measure and be gone.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Give me a torch. I am not for this ambling.
Being but heavy I will bear the light.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.l: Nay, gentle Romeo, we must have you dance.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Not I, believe me. You have dancing shoes
With nimble soles. I have a soul of lead
So stakes me to the ground I cannot move.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.l: You are a lover. Borrow Cupid’s wings
And soar with them above a common bound.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: I am too sore enpiercèd with his shaft
To soar with his light feathers, and so bound
I cannot bound a pitch above dull woe.
Under love’s heavy burden do I sink.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.l: And to sink in it should you burden love—
Too great oppression for a tender thing.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Is love a tender thing? It is too rough,
Too rude, too boist’rous, and it pricks like thorn.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.l: If love be rough with you, be rough with love.
Prick love for pricking, and you beat love down.—
Give me a case to put my visage in.—
A visor for a visor. What care I
What curious eye doth cote deformities?
Here are the beetle brows shall blush for me.

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: Come, knock and enter, and no sooner in
But every man betake him to his legs.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: A torch for me. Let wantons light of heart
Tickle the senseless rushes with their heels,
For I am proverbed with a grandsire phrase:
I’ll be a candle holder and look on;
The game was ne’er so fair, and I am done.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.l: Tut, dun’s the mouse, the constable’s own word.
If thou art dun, we’ll draw thee from the mire—
Or, save your reverence, love— wherein thou stickest
Up to the ears. Come, we burn daylight, ho!

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Nay, that’s not so.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.l: I mean, sir, in delay
We waste our lights; in vain, light lights by day.
Take our good meaning, for our judgment sits
Five times in that ere once in our five wits.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: And we mean well in going to this masque,
But ’tis no wit to go.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.l: Why, may one ask?

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: I dreamt a dream tonight.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.l: And so did I.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Well, what was yours?

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.l: That dreamers often lie.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: In bed asleep while they do dream things true.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.l: O, then I see Queen Mab hath been with you.
She is the fairies’ midwife, and she comes
In shape no bigger than an agate stone
On the forefinger of an alderman,
Drawn with a team of little atomi
Over men’s noses as they lie asleep.
Her wagon spokes made of long spinners’ legs,
The cover of the wings of grasshoppers,
Her traces of the smallest spider web,
Her collars of the moonshine’s wat’ry beams,
Her whip of cricket’s bone, the lash of film,
Her wagoner a small gray-coated gnat,
Not half so big as a round little worm
Pricked from the lazy finger of a maid.
Her chariot is an empty hazelnut,
Made by the joiner squirrel or old grub,
Time out o’ mind the fairies’ coachmakers.
And in this state she gallops night by night
Through lovers’ brains, and then they dream of love;
On courtiers’ knees, that dream on cur’sies straight;
O’er lawyers’ fingers, who straight dream on fees;
O’er ladies’ lips, who straight on kisses dream,
Which oft the angry Mab with blisters plagues
Because their breaths with sweetmeats tainted are.
Sometime she gallops o’er a courtier’s nose,
And then dreams he of smelling out a suit.
And sometime comes she with a tithe-pig’s tail,
Tickling a parson’s nose as he lies asleep;
Then he dreams of another benefice.
Sometime she driveth o’er a soldier’s neck,
And then dreams he of cutting foreign throats,
Of breaches, ambuscadoes, Spanish blades,
Of healths five fathom deep, and then anon
Drums in his ear, at which he starts and wakes
And, being thus frighted, swears a prayer or two
And sleeps again. This is that very Mab
That plats the manes of horses in the night
And bakes the elflocks in foul sluttish hairs,
Which once untangled much misfortune bodes.
This is the hag, when maids lie on their backs,
That presses them and learns them first to bear,
Making them women of good carriage.
This is she—

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Peace, peace, Mercutio, peace.
Thou talk’st of nothing.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.l: True, I talk of dreams,
Which are the children of an idle brain,
Begot of nothing but vain fantasy,
Which is as thin of substance as the air
And more inconstant than the wind, who woos
Even now the frozen bosom of the north
And, being angered, puffs away from thence,
Turning his side to the dew-dropping south.

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: This wind you talk of blows us from ourselves.
Supper is done, and we shall come too late.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: I fear too early, for my mind misgives
Some consequence yet hanging in the stars
Shall bitterly begin his fearful date
With this night’s revels, and expire the term
Of a despisèd life closed in my breast
By some vile forfeit of untimely death.
But he that hath the steerage of my course
Direct my sail. On, lusty gentlemen.

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.p: Strike, drum.

div.stage: They march about the stage and then withdraw to the side.

div.head: Scene 5

sp.speaker: FIRST SERVINGMAN
sp.p:
Where’s Potpan that he helps not
to take away? He shift a trencher? He scrape a
trencher?

sp.speaker: SECOND SERVINGMAN
sp.p:
When good manners shall lie
all in one or two men’s hands, and they unwashed
too, ’tis a foul thing.

sp.speaker: FIRST SERVINGMAN
sp.p:
Away with the joint stools, remove
the court cupboard, look to the plate.—
Good thou, save me a piece of marchpane, and, as
thou loves me, let the porter let in Susan Grindstone
and Nell.— Anthony and Potpan!

sp.speaker: THIRD SERVINGMAN
sp.p: Ay, boy, ready.

sp.speaker: FIRST SERVINGMAN
sp.p:
You are looked for and called for,
asked for and sought for, in the great chamber.

sp.speaker: THIRD SERVINGMAN
sp.p:
We cannot be here and there too.
Cheerly, boys! Be brisk awhile, and the longer liver
take all.

div.stage: Enter Capulet and his household, all the guests and gentlewomen to Romeo, Mercutio, Benvolio, and the other Maskers.

sp.speaker: CAPULET
sp.l: Welcome, gentlemen. Ladies that have their toes
Unplagued with corns will walk a bout with you.—
Ah, my mistresses, which of you all
Will now deny to dance? She that makes dainty,
She, I’ll swear, hath corns. Am I come near you now?—
Welcome, gentlemen. I have seen the day
That I have worn a visor and could tell
A whispering tale in a fair lady’s ear,
Such as would please. ’Tis gone, ’tis gone, ’tis gone.
You are welcome, gentlemen.— Come, musicians, play.
A hall, a hall, give room!— And foot it, girls.—
More light, you knaves, and turn the tables up,
And quench the fire; the room is grown too hot.—
Ah, sirrah, this unlooked-for sport comes well.—
Nay, sit, nay, sit, good cousin Capulet,
For you and I are past our dancing days.
How long is ’t now since last yourself and I
Were in a mask?

sp.speaker: CAPULET’S COUSIN
sp.l: By ’r Lady, thirty years.

sp.speaker: CAPULET
sp.l: What, man, ’tis not so much, ’tis not so much.
’Tis since the nuptial of Lucentio,
Come Pentecost as quickly as it will,
Some five and twenty years, and then we masked.

sp.speaker: CAPULET’S COUSIN
sp.l: ’Tis more, ’tis more. His son is elder, sir.
His son is thirty.

sp.speaker: CAPULET
sp.l: Will you tell me that?
His son was but a ward two years ago.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: What lady’s that which doth enrich the hand
Of yonder knight?

sp.speaker: SERVINGMAN
sp.p: I know not, sir.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: O, she doth teach the torches to burn bright!
It seems she hangs upon the cheek of night
As a rich jewel in an Ethiop’s ear—
Beauty too rich for use, for Earth too dear.
So shows a snowy dove trooping with crows
As yonder lady o’er her fellows shows.
The measure done, I’ll watch her place of stand
And, touching hers, make blessèd my rude hand.
Did my heart love till now? Forswear it, sight,
For I ne’er saw true beauty till this night.

sp.speaker: TYBALT
sp.l: This, by his voice, should be a Montague.—
Fetch me my rapier, boy.
What, dares the slave
Come hither covered with an antic face
To fleer and scorn at our solemnity?
Now, by the stock and honor of my kin,
To strike him dead I hold it not a sin.

sp.speaker: CAPULET
sp.l: Why, how now, kinsman? Wherefore storm you so?

sp.speaker: TYBALT
sp.l: Uncle, this is a Montague, our foe,
A villain that is hither come in spite
To scorn at our solemnity this night.

sp.speaker: CAPULET
sp.l: Young Romeo is it?

sp.speaker: TYBALT
sp.l: ’Tis he, that villain Romeo.

sp.speaker: CAPULET
sp.l: Content thee, gentle coz. Let him alone.
He bears him like a portly gentleman,
And, to say truth, Verona brags of him
To be a virtuous and well-governed youth.
I would not for the wealth of all this town
Here in my house do him disparagement.
Therefore be patient. Take no note of him.
It is my will, the which if thou respect,
Show a fair presence and put off these frowns,
An ill-beseeming semblance for a feast.

sp.speaker: TYBALT
sp.l: It fits when such a villain is a guest.
I’ll not endure him.

sp.speaker: CAPULET
sp.l: He shall be endured.
What, goodman boy? I say he shall. Go to.
Am I the master here or you? Go to.
You’ll not endure him! God shall mend my soul,
You’ll make a mutiny among my guests,
You will set cock-a-hoop, you’ll be the man!

sp.speaker: TYBALT
sp.l: Why, uncle, ’tis a shame.

sp.speaker: CAPULET
sp.l: Go to, go to.
You are a saucy boy. Is ’t so indeed?
This trick may chance to scathe you. I know what.
You must contrary me. Marry, ’tis time—
Well said, my hearts.— You are a princox, go.
Be quiet, or— More light, more light!— for shame,
I’ll make you quiet.— What, cheerly, my hearts!

sp.speaker: TYBALT
sp.l: Patience perforce with willful choler meeting
Makes my flesh tremble in their different greeting.
I will withdraw, but this intrusion shall,
Now seeming sweet, convert to bitt’rest gall.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: If I profane with my unworthiest hand
This holy shrine, the gentle sin is this:
My lips, two blushing pilgrims, ready stand
To smooth that rough touch with a tender kiss.

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: Good pilgrim, you do wrong your hand too much,
Which mannerly devotion shows in this;
For saints have hands that pilgrims’ hands do touch,
And palm to palm is holy palmers’ kiss.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Have not saints lips, and holy palmers too?

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: Ay, pilgrim, lips that they must use in prayer.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: O then, dear saint, let lips do what hands do.
They pray: grant thou, lest faith turn to despair.

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: Saints do not move, though grant for prayers’ sake.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Then move not while my prayer’s effect I take.
Thus from my lips, by thine, my sin is purged.

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: Then have my lips the sin that they have took.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Sin from my lips? O trespass sweetly urged!
Give me my sin again.

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: You kiss by th’ book.

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.l: Madam, your mother craves a word with you.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: What is her mother?

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.l: Marry, bachelor,
Her mother is the lady of the house,
And a good lady, and a wise and virtuous.
I nursed her daughter that you talked withal.
I tell you, he that can lay hold of her
Shall have the chinks.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Is she a Capulet?
O dear account! My life is my foe’s debt.

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: Away, begone. The sport is at the best.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Ay, so I fear. The more is my unrest.

sp.speaker: CAPULET
sp.l: Nay, gentlemen, prepare not to be gone.
We have a trifling foolish banquet towards.—
Is it e’en so? Why then, I thank you all.
I thank you, honest gentlemen. Good night.—
More torches here.— Come on then, let’s to bed.—
Ah, sirrah, by my fay, it waxes late.
I’ll to my rest.

div.stage: All but Juliet and the Nurse begin to exit.

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: Come hither, nurse. What is yond gentleman?

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.l: The son and heir of old Tiberio.

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: What’s he that now is going out of door?

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.l: Marry, that, I think, be young Petruchio.

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: What’s he that follows here, that would not dance?

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: I know not.

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: Go ask his name. The Nurse goes. If he be marrièd,
My grave is like to be my wedding bed.

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.l: His name is Romeo, and a Montague,
The only son of your great enemy.

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: My only love sprung from my only hate!
Too early seen unknown, and known too late!
Prodigious birth of love it is to me
That I must love a loathèd enemy.

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.l: What’s this? What’s this?

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: A rhyme I learned even now
Of one I danced withal.

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.l: Anon, anon.
Come, let’s away. The strangers all are gone.
Now old desire doth in his deathbed lie,
And young affection gapes to be his heir.
That fair for which love groaned for and would die,
With tender Juliet matched, is now not fair.
Now Romeo is beloved and loves again,
Alike bewitchèd by the charm of looks,
But to his foe supposed he must complain,
And she steal love’s sweet bait from fearful hooks.
Being held a foe, he may not have access
To breathe such vows as lovers use to swear,
And she as much in love, her means much less
To meet her new belovèd anywhere.
But passion lends them power, time means, to meet,
Temp’ring extremities with extreme sweet.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Can I go forward when my heart is here?
Turn back, dull earth, and find thy center out.

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: Romeo, my cousin Romeo, Romeo!

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.l: He is wise
And, on my life, hath stol’n him home to bed.

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: He ran this way and leapt this orchard wall.
Call, good Mercutio.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.l: Nay, I’ll conjure too.
Romeo! Humors! Madman! Passion! Lover!
Appear thou in the likeness of a sigh.
Speak but one rhyme and I am satisfied.
Cry but “ Ay me,” pronounce but “ love” and “ dove.”
Speak to my gossip Venus one fair word,
One nickname for her purblind son and heir,
Young Abraham Cupid, he that shot so trim
When King Cophetua loved the beggar maid.—
He heareth not, he stirreth not, he moveth not.
The ape is dead, and I must conjure him.—
I conjure thee by Rosaline’s bright eyes,
By her high forehead, and her scarlet lip,
By her fine foot, straight leg, and quivering thigh,
And the demesnes that there adjacent lie,
That in thy likeness thou appear to us.

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: An if he hear thee, thou wilt anger him.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.l: This cannot anger him. ’Twould anger him
To raise a spirit in his mistress’ circle
Of some strange nature, letting it there stand
Till she had laid it and conjured it down.
That were some spite. My invocation
Is fair and honest. In his mistress’ name,
I conjure only but to raise up him.

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: Come, he hath hid himself among these trees
To be consorted with the humorous night.
Blind is his love and best befits the dark.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.l: If love be blind, love cannot hit the mark.
Now will he sit under a medlar tree
And wish his mistress were that kind of fruit
As maids call medlars when they laugh alone.—
O Romeo, that she were, O, that she were
An open-arse, thou a pop’rin pear.
Romeo, good night. I’ll to my truckle bed;
This field-bed is too cold for me to sleep.—
Come, shall we go?

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: Go, then, for ’tis in vain
To seek him here that means not to be found.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: He jests at scars that never felt a wound.
But soft, what light through yonder window breaks?
It is the East, and Juliet is the sun.
Arise, fair sun, and kill the envious moon,
Who is already sick and pale with grief
That thou, her maid, art far more fair than she.
Be not her maid since she is envious.
Her vestal livery is but sick and green,
And none but fools do wear it. Cast it off.
It is my lady. O, it is my love!
O, that she knew she were!
She speaks, yet she says nothing. What of that?
Her eye discourses; I will answer it.
I am too bold. ’Tis not to me she speaks.
Two of the fairest stars in all the heaven,
Having some business, do entreat her eyes
To twinkle in their spheres till they return.
What if her eyes were there, they in her head?
The brightness of her cheek would shame those stars
As daylight doth a lamp; her eye in heaven
Would through the airy region stream so bright
That birds would sing and think it were not night.
See how she leans her cheek upon her hand.
O, that I were a glove upon that hand,
That I might touch that cheek!

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: Ay me.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: She speaks.
O, speak again, bright angel, for thou art
As glorious to this night, being o’er my head,
As is a wingèd messenger of heaven
Unto the white-upturnèd wond’ring eyes
Of mortals that fall back to gaze on him
When he bestrides the lazy puffing clouds
And sails upon the bosom of the air.

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: O Romeo, Romeo, wherefore art thou Romeo?
Deny thy father and refuse thy name,
Or, if thou wilt not, be but sworn my love,
And I’ll no longer be a Capulet.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Shall I hear more, or shall I speak at this?

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: ’Tis but thy name that is my enemy.
Thou art thyself, though not a Montague.
What’s Montague? It is nor hand, nor foot,
Nor arm, nor face. O, be some other name
Belonging to a man.
What’s in a name? That which we call a rose
By any other word would smell as sweet.
So Romeo would, were he not Romeo called,
Retain that dear perfection which he owes
Without that title. Romeo, doff thy name,
And, for thy name, which is no part of thee,
Take all myself.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: I take thee at thy word.
Call me but love, and I’ll be new baptized.
Henceforth I never will be Romeo.

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: What man art thou that, thus bescreened in night,
So stumblest on my counsel?

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: By a name
I know not how to tell thee who I am.
My name, dear saint, is hateful to myself
Because it is an enemy to thee.
Had I it written, I would tear the word.

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: My ears have yet not drunk a hundred words
Of thy tongue’s uttering, yet I know the sound.
Art thou not Romeo, and a Montague?

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Neither, fair maid, if either thee dislike.

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: How camest thou hither, tell me, and wherefore?
The orchard walls are high and hard to climb,
And the place death, considering who thou art,
If any of my kinsmen find thee here.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: With love’s light wings did I o’erperch these walls,
For stony limits cannot hold love out,
And what love can do, that dares love attempt.
Therefore thy kinsmen are no stop to me.

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: If they do see thee, they will murder thee.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Alack, there lies more peril in thine eye
Than twenty of their swords. Look thou but sweet,
And I am proof against their enmity.

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: I would not for the world they saw thee here.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: I have night’s cloak to hide me from their eyes,
And, but thou love me, let them find me here.
My life were better ended by their hate
Than death proroguèd, wanting of thy love.

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: By whose direction found’st thou out this place?

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: By love, that first did prompt me to inquire.
He lent me counsel, and I lent him eyes.
I am no pilot; yet, wert thou as far
As that vast shore washed with the farthest sea,
I should adventure for such merchandise.

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: Thou knowest the mask of night is on my face,
Else would a maiden blush bepaint my cheek
For that which thou hast heard me speak tonight.
Fain would I dwell on form; fain, fain deny
What I have spoke. But farewell compliment.
Dost thou love me? I know thou wilt say “ Ay,”
And I will take thy word. Yet, if thou swear’st,
Thou mayst prove false. At lovers’ perjuries,
They say, Jove laughs. O gentle Romeo,
If thou dost love, pronounce it faithfully.
Or, if thou thinkest I am too quickly won,
I’ll frown and be perverse and say thee nay,
So thou wilt woo, but else not for the world.
In truth, fair Montague, I am too fond,
And therefore thou mayst think my havior light.
But trust me, gentleman, I’ll prove more true
Than those that have more coying to be strange.
I should have been more strange, I must confess,
But that thou overheard’st ere I was ware
My true-love passion. Therefore pardon me,
And not impute this yielding to light love,
Which the dark night hath so discoverèd.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Lady, by yonder blessèd moon I vow,
That tips with silver all these fruit-tree tops—

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: O, swear not by the moon, th’ inconstant moon,
That monthly changes in her circled orb,
Lest that thy love prove likewise variable.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: What shall I swear by?

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: Do not swear at all.
Or, if thou wilt, swear by thy gracious self,
Which is the god of my idolatry,
And I’ll believe thee.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: If my heart’s dear love—

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: Well, do not swear. Although I joy in thee,
I have no joy of this contract tonight.
It is too rash, too unadvised, too sudden,
Too like the lightning, which doth cease to be
Ere one can say “ It lightens.” Sweet, good night.
This bud of love, by summer’s ripening breath,
May prove a beauteous flower when next we meet.
Good night, good night. As sweet repose and rest
Come to thy heart as that within my breast.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: O, wilt thou leave me so unsatisfied?

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: What satisfaction canst thou have tonight?

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Th’ exchange of thy love’s faithful vow for mine.

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: I gave thee mine before thou didst request it,
And yet I would it were to give again.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Wouldst thou withdraw it? For what purpose, love?

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: But to be frank and give it thee again.
And yet I wish but for the thing I have.
My bounty is as boundless as the sea,
My love as deep. The more I give to thee,
The more I have, for both are infinite.
I hear some noise within. Dear love, adieu.—
Anon, good nurse.— Sweet Montague, be true.
Stay but a little; I will come again.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: O blessèd, blessèd night! I am afeard,
Being in night, all this is but a dream,
Too flattering sweet to be substantial.

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: Three words, dear Romeo, and good night indeed.
If that thy bent of love be honorable,
Thy purpose marriage, send me word tomorrow,
By one that I’ll procure to come to thee,
Where and what time thou wilt perform the rite,
And all my fortunes at thy foot I’ll lay
And follow thee my lord throughout the world.

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: I come anon.— But if thou meanest not well,
I do beseech thee—

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: By and by, I come.—
To cease thy strife and leave me to my grief.
Tomorrow will I send.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: So thrive my soul—

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: A thousand times good night.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: A thousand times the worse to want thy light.
Love goes toward love as schoolboys from their books,
But love from love, toward school with heavy looks.

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: Hist, Romeo, hist! O, for a falc’ner’s voice
To lure this tassel-gentle back again!
Bondage is hoarse and may not speak aloud,
Else would I tear the cave where Echo lies
And make her airy tongue more hoarse than mine
With repetition of “ My Romeo!”

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: It is my soul that calls upon my name.
How silver-sweet sound lovers’ tongues by night,
Like softest music to attending ears.

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: Romeo.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: My dear.

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: What o’clock tomorrow
Shall I send to thee?

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: By the hour of nine.

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: I will not fail. ’Tis twenty year till then.
I have forgot why I did call thee back.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Let me stand here till thou remember it.

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: I shall forget, to have thee still stand there,
Rememb’ring how I love thy company.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: And I’ll still stay, to have thee still forget,
Forgetting any other home but this.

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: ’Tis almost morning. I would have thee gone,
And yet no farther than a wanton’s bird,
That lets it hop a little from his hand,
Like a poor prisoner in his twisted gyves,
And with a silken thread plucks it back again,
So loving-jealous of his liberty.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: I would I were thy bird.

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: Sweet, so would I.
Yet I should kill thee with much cherishing.
Good night, good night. Parting is such sweet sorrow
That I shall say “ Good night” till it be morrow.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Sleep dwell upon thine eyes, peace in thy breast.
Would I were sleep and peace so sweet to rest.
Hence will I to my ghostly friar’s close cell,
His help to crave, and my dear hap to tell.

div.head: Scene 3
div.stage: Enter Friar Lawrence alone with a basket.

sp.speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
sp.l: The gray-eyed morn smiles on the frowning night,
Check’ring the eastern clouds with streaks of light,
And fleckled darkness like a drunkard reels
From forth day’s path and Titan’s fiery wheels.
Now, ere the sun advance his burning eye,
The day to cheer and night’s dank dew to dry,
I must upfill this osier cage of ours
With baleful weeds and precious-juicèd flowers.
The Earth that’s nature’s mother is her tomb;
What is her burying grave, that is her womb;
And from her womb children of divers kind
We sucking on her natural bosom find,
Many for many virtues excellent,
None but for some, and yet all different.
O, mickle is the powerful grace that lies
In plants, herbs, stones, and their true qualities.
For naught so vile that on the Earth doth live
But to the Earth some special good doth give;
Nor aught so good but, strained from that fair use,
Revolts from true birth, stumbling on abuse.
Virtue itself turns vice, being misapplied,
And vice sometime by action dignified.
Within the infant rind of this weak flower
Poison hath residence and medicine power:
For this, being smelt, with that part cheers each part;
Being tasted, stays all senses with the heart.
Two such opposèd kings encamp them still
In man as well as herbs— grace and rude will;
And where the worser is predominant,
Full soon the canker death eats up that plant.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Good morrow, father.

sp.speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
sp.l: Benedicite.
What early tongue so sweet saluteth me?
Young son, it argues a distempered head
So soon to bid “ Good morrow” to thy bed.
Care keeps his watch in every old man’s eye,
And, where care lodges, sleep will never lie;
But where unbruisèd youth with unstuffed brain
Doth couch his limbs, there golden sleep doth reign.
Therefore thy earliness doth me assure
Thou art uproused with some distemp’rature,
Or, if not so, then here I hit it right:
Our Romeo hath not been in bed tonight.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: That last is true. The sweeter rest was mine.

sp.speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
sp.l: God pardon sin! Wast thou with Rosaline?

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: With Rosaline, my ghostly father? No.
I have forgot that name and that name’s woe.

sp.speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
sp.l: That’s my good son. But where hast thou been then?

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: I’ll tell thee ere thou ask it me again.
I have been feasting with mine enemy,
Where on a sudden one hath wounded me
That’s by me wounded. Both our remedies
Within thy help and holy physic lies.
I bear no hatred, blessèd man, for, lo,
My intercession likewise steads my foe.

sp.speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
sp.l: Be plain, good son, and homely in thy drift.
Riddling confession finds but riddling shrift.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Then plainly know my heart’s dear love is set
On the fair daughter of rich Capulet.
As mine on hers, so hers is set on mine,
And all combined, save what thou must combine
By holy marriage. When and where and how
We met, we wooed, and made exchange of vow
I’ll tell thee as we pass, but this I pray,
That thou consent to marry us today.

sp.speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
sp.l: Holy Saint Francis, what a change is here!
Is Rosaline, that thou didst love so dear,
So soon forsaken? Young men’s love then lies
Not truly in their hearts, but in their eyes.
Jesu Maria, what a deal of brine
Hath washed thy sallow cheeks for Rosaline!
How much salt water thrown away in waste
To season love, that of it doth not taste!
The sun not yet thy sighs from heaven clears,
Thy old groans yet ringing in mine ancient ears.
Lo, here upon thy cheek the stain doth sit
Of an old tear that is not washed off yet.
If e’er thou wast thyself, and these woes thine,
Thou and these woes were all for Rosaline.
And art thou changed? Pronounce this sentence then:
Women may fall when there’s no strength in men.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Thou chid’st me oft for loving Rosaline.

sp.speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
sp.l: For doting, not for loving, pupil mine.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: And bad’st me bury love.

sp.speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
sp.l: Not in a grave
To lay one in, another out to have.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: I pray thee, chide me not. Her I love now
Doth grace for grace and love for love allow.
The other did not so.

sp.speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
sp.l: O, she knew well
Thy love did read by rote, that could not spell.
But come, young waverer, come, go with me.
In one respect I’ll thy assistant be,
For this alliance may so happy prove
To turn your households’ rancor to pure love.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: O, let us hence. I stand on sudden haste.

sp.speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
sp.l: Wisely and slow. They stumble that run fast.

div.head: Scene 4

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.l: Where the devil should this Romeo be?
Came he not home tonight?

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: Not to his father’s. I spoke with his man.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.l: Why, that same pale hard-hearted wench, that Rosaline,
Torments him so that he will sure run mad.

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: Tybalt, the kinsman to old Capulet,
Hath sent a letter to his father’s house.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.p: A challenge, on my life.

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.p: Romeo will answer it.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.p: Any man that can write may answer a letter.

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.p:
Nay, he will answer the letter’s master, how
he dares, being dared.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.p:
Alas, poor Romeo, he is already dead,
stabbed with a white wench’s black eye, run
through the ear with a love-song, the very pin of his
heart cleft with the blind bow-boy’s butt shaft. And
is he a man to encounter Tybalt?

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.p: Why, what is Tybalt?

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.p:
More than prince of cats. O, he’s the courageous
captain of compliments. He fights as you sing
prick-song, keeps time, distance, and proportion.
He rests his minim rests, one, two, and the third in
your bosom— the very butcher of a silk button, a
duelist, a duelist, a gentleman of the very first house
of the first and second cause. Ah, the immortal
passado, the punto reverso, the hay!

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.p: The what?

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.p:
The pox of such antic, lisping, affecting
phantasimes, these new tuners of accent: “ By
Jesu, a very good blade! A very tall man! A very good
whore!” Why, is not this a lamentable thing, grandsire,
that we should be thus afflicted with these
strange flies, these fashion-mongers, these “pardon-me” ’s,
who stand so much on the new form
that they cannot sit at ease on the old bench? O their
bones, their bones!

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.p: Here comes Romeo, here comes Romeo.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.p:
Without his roe, like a dried herring. O
flesh, flesh, how art thou fishified! Now is he for the
numbers that Petrarch flowed in. Laura to his lady
was a kitchen wench ( marry, she had a better love
to berhyme her), Dido a dowdy, Cleopatra a gypsy,
Helen and Hero hildings and harlots, Thisbe a gray
eye or so, but not to the purpose.— Signior Romeo,
bonjour. There’s a French salutation to your French
slop. You gave us the counterfeit fairly last night.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.p:
Good morrow to you both. What counterfeit
did I give you?

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.p: The slip, sir, the slip. Can you not conceive?

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.p:
Pardon, good Mercutio, my business was
great, and in such a case as mine a man may strain
courtesy.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.p:
That’s as much as to say such a case as
yours constrains a man to bow in the hams.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.p: Meaning, to curtsy.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.p: Thou hast most kindly hit it.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.p: A most courteous exposition.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.p: Nay, I am the very pink of courtesy.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.p: “ Pink” for flower.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.p: Right.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.p: Why, then is my pump well flowered.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.p:
Sure wit, follow me this jest now till thou
hast worn out thy pump, that when the single sole
of it is worn, the jest may remain, after the wearing,
solely singular.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.p:
O single-soled jest, solely singular for the
singleness.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.p:
Come between us, good Benvolio. My wits
faints.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.p:
Switch and spurs, switch and spurs, or I’ll cry
a match.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.p:
Nay, if our wits run the wild-goose chase, I
am done, for thou hast more of the wild goose in
one of thy wits than, I am sure, I have in my whole
five. Was I with you there for the goose?

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.p:
Thou wast never with me for anything when
thou wast not there for the goose.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.p: I will bite thee by the ear for that jest.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.p: Nay, good goose, bite not.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.p:
Thy wit is a very bitter sweeting; it is a most
sharp sauce.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.p:
And is it not, then, well served into a sweet
goose?

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.p:
O, here’s a wit of cheveril that stretches
from an inch narrow to an ell broad.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.p:
I stretch it out for that word “ broad,” which
added to the goose, proves thee far and wide a
broad goose.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.p:
Why, is not this better now than groaning
for love? Now art thou sociable, now art thou
Romeo, now art thou what thou art, by art as well as
by nature. For this driveling love is like a great
natural that runs lolling up and down to hide his
bauble in a hole.

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.p: Stop there, stop there.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.p:
Thou desirest me to stop in my tale against
the hair.

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.p: Thou wouldst else have made thy tale large.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.p:
O, thou art deceived. I would have made it
short, for I was come to the whole depth of my tale
and meant indeed to occupy the argument no
longer.

div.stage: Enter Nurse and her man Peter.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.p: Here’s goodly gear. A sail, a sail!

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.p: Two, two— a shirt and a smock.

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: Peter.

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Anon.

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: My fan, Peter.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.p:
Good Peter, to hide her face, for her fan’s
the fairer face.

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: God you good morrow, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.p: God you good e’en, fair gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: Is it good e’en?

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.p:
’Tis no less, I tell you, for the bawdy hand of
the dial is now upon the prick of noon.

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: Out upon you! What a man are you?

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.p:
One, gentlewoman, that God hath made, himself
to mar.

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p:
By my troth, it is well said: “ for himself to
mar,” quoth he? Gentlemen, can any of you tell me
where I may find the young Romeo?

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.p:
I can tell you, but young Romeo will be older
when you have found him than he was when you
sought him. I am the youngest of that name, for
fault of a worse.

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: You say well.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.p:
Yea, is the worst well? Very well took, i’
faith, wisely, wisely.

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p:
If you be he, sir, I desire some confidence with
you.

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.p: She will indite him to some supper.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.p: A bawd, a bawd, a bawd. So ho!

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.p: What hast thou found?

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.p:
No hare, sir, unless a hare, sir, in a Lenten
pie that is something stale and hoar ere it be spent.

lg.l: Is very good meat in Lent.
But a hare that is hoar
Is too much for a score
When it hoars ere it be spent.

sp.p:
Romeo, will you come to your father’s? We’ll to
dinner thither.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.p: I will follow you.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.p:
Farewell, ancient lady. Farewell, lady, lady,
lady.

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p:
I pray you, sir, what saucy merchant was this
that was so full of his ropery?

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.p:
A gentleman, nurse, that loves to hear himself
talk and will speak more in a minute than he will
stand to in a month.

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p:
An he speak anything against me, I’ll take him
down, an he were lustier than he is, and twenty
such jacks. An if I cannot, I’ll find those that shall.
Scurvy knave, I am none of his flirt-gills; I am none
of his skains-mates. To Peter. And thou must stand
by too and suffer every knave to use me at his
pleasure.

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p:
I saw no man use you at his pleasure. If I had,
my weapon should quickly have been out. I warrant
you, I dare draw as soon as another man, if I
see occasion in a good quarrel, and the law on my
side.

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p:
Now, afore God, I am so vexed that every part
about me quivers. Scurvy knave! To Romeo. Pray
you, sir, a word. And, as I told you, my young lady
bid me inquire you out. What she bid me say, I will
keep to myself. But first let me tell you, if you
should lead her in a fool’s paradise, as they say, it
were a very gross kind of behavior, as they say. For
the gentlewoman is young; and therefore, if you
should deal double with her, truly it were an ill
thing to be offered to any gentlewoman, and very
weak dealing.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.p:
Nurse, commend me to thy lady and mistress.
I protest unto thee—

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p:
Good heart, and i’ faith I will tell her as much.
Lord, Lord, she will be a joyful woman.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.p:
What wilt thou tell her, nurse? Thou dost not
mark me.

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p:
I will tell her, sir, that you do protest, which, as
I take it, is a gentlemanlike offer.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Bid her devise
Some means to come to shrift this afternoon,
And there she shall at Friar Lawrence’ cell
Be shrived and married. Here is for thy pains.

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: No, truly, sir, not a penny.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.p: Go to, I say you shall.

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.l: This afternoon, sir? Well, she shall be there.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: And stay, good nurse, behind the abbey wall.
Within this hour my man shall be with thee
And bring thee cords made like a tackled stair,
Which to the high topgallant of my joy
Must be my convoy in the secret night.
Farewell. Be trusty, and I’ll quit thy pains.
Farewell. Commend me to thy mistress.

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.l: Now, God in heaven bless thee! Hark you, sir.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: What sayst thou, my dear nurse?

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.l: Is your man secret? Did you ne’er hear say
“ Two may keep counsel, putting one away”?

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Warrant thee, my man’s as true as steel.

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p:
Well, sir, my mistress is the sweetest lady. Lord,
Lord, when ’twas a little prating thing— O, there is
a nobleman in town, one Paris, that would fain lay
knife aboard, but she, good soul, had as lief see a
toad, a very toad, as see him. I anger her sometimes
and tell her that Paris is the properer man, but I’ll
warrant you, when I say so, she looks as pale as any
clout in the versal world. Doth not rosemary and
Romeo begin both with a letter?

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.p: Ay, nurse, what of that? Both with an R.

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p:
Ah, mocker, that’s the dog’s name. R is for
the— No, I know it begins with some other letter,
and she hath the prettiest sententious of it, of you
and rosemary, that it would do you good to hear it.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.p: Commend me to thy lady.

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: Ay, a thousand times.— Peter.

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Anon.

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: Before and apace.

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: The clock struck nine when I did send the Nurse.
In half an hour she promised to return.
Perchance she cannot meet him. That’s not so.
O, she is lame! Love’s heralds should be thoughts,
Which ten times faster glides than the sun’s beams,
Driving back shadows over louring hills.
Therefore do nimble-pinioned doves draw Love,
And therefore hath the wind-swift Cupid wings.
Now is the sun upon the highmost hill
Of this day’s journey, and from nine till twelve
Is three long hours, yet she is not come.
Had she affections and warm youthful blood,
She would be as swift in motion as a ball;
My words would bandy her to my sweet love,
And his to me.
But old folks, many feign as they were dead,
Unwieldy, slow, heavy, and pale as lead.
O God, she comes!— O, honey nurse, what news?
Hast thou met with him? Send thy man away.

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: Peter, stay at the gate.

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: Now, good sweet nurse— O Lord, why lookest thou sad?
Though news be sad, yet tell them merrily.
If good, thou shamest the music of sweet news
By playing it to me with so sour a face.

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.l: I am aweary. Give me leave awhile.
Fie, how my bones ache! What a jaunt have I!

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: I would thou hadst my bones, and I thy news.
Nay, come, I pray thee, speak. Good, good nurse, speak.

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.l: Jesu, what haste! Can you not stay awhile?
Do you not see that I am out of breath?

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: How art thou out of breath, when thou hast breath
To say to me that thou art out of breath?
The excuse that thou dost make in this delay
Is longer than the tale thou dost excuse.
Is thy news good or bad? Answer to that.
Say either, and I’ll stay the circumstance.
Let me be satisfied; is ’t good or bad?

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p:
Well, you have made a simple choice. You know
not how to choose a man. Romeo? No, not he.
Though his face be better than any man’s, yet his leg
excels all men’s, and for a hand and a foot and a
body, though they be not to be talked on, yet they
are past compare. He is not the flower of courtesy,
but I’ll warrant him as gentle as a lamb. Go thy
ways, wench. Serve God. What, have you dined at
home?

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: No, no. But all this did I know before.
What says he of our marriage? What of that?

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.l: Lord, how my head aches! What a head have I!
It beats as it would fall in twenty pieces.
My back o’ t’ other side! Ah, my back, my back!
Beshrew your heart for sending me about
To catch my death with jaunting up and down.

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: I’ faith, I am sorry that thou art not well.
Sweet, sweet, sweet nurse, tell me, what says my love?

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p:
Your love says, like an honest gentleman, and a
courteous, and a kind, and a handsome, and, I
warrant, a virtuous— Where is your mother?

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: Where is my mother? Why, she is within.
Where should she be? How oddly thou repliest:
“ Your love says, like an honest gentleman,
Where is your mother?”

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.l: O God’s lady dear,
Are you so hot? Marry, come up, I trow.
Is this the poultice for my aching bones?
Henceforward do your messages yourself.

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: Here’s such a coil. Come, what says Romeo?

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.l: Have you got leave to go to shrift today?

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.p: I have.

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.l: Then hie you hence to Friar Lawrence’ cell.
There stays a husband to make you a wife.
Now comes the wanton blood up in your cheeks;
They’ll be in scarlet straight at any news.
Hie you to church. I must another way,
To fetch a ladder by the which your love
Must climb a bird’s nest soon when it is dark.
I am the drudge and toil in your delight,
But you shall bear the burden soon at night.
Go. I’ll to dinner. Hie you to the cell.

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: Hie to high fortune! Honest nurse, farewell.

sp.speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
sp.l: So smile the heavens upon this holy act
That after-hours with sorrow chide us not.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Amen, amen. But come what sorrow can,
It cannot countervail the exchange of joy
That one short minute gives me in her sight.
Do thou but close our hands with holy words,
Then love-devouring death do what he dare,
It is enough I may but call her mine.

sp.speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
sp.l: These violent delights have violent ends
And in their triumph die, like fire and powder,
Which, as they kiss, consume. The sweetest honey
Is loathsome in his own deliciousness
And in the taste confounds the appetite.
Therefore love moderately. Long love doth so.
Too swift arrives as tardy as too slow.
Here comes the lady. O, so light a foot
Will ne’er wear out the everlasting flint.
A lover may bestride the gossamers
That idles in the wanton summer air,
And yet not fall, so light is vanity.

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: Good even to my ghostly confessor.

sp.speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
sp.l: Romeo shall thank thee, daughter, for us both.

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: As much to him, else is his thanks too much.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Ah, Juliet, if the measure of thy joy
Be heaped like mine, and that thy skill be more
To blazon it, then sweeten with thy breath
This neighbor air, and let rich music’s tongue
Unfold the imagined happiness that both
Receive in either by this dear encounter.

sp.speaker: JULIET
sp.l: Conceit, more rich in matter than in words,
Brags of his substance, not of ornament.
They are but beggars that can count their worth,
But my true love is grown to such excess
I cannot sum up sum of half my wealth.

sp.speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
sp.l: Come, come with me, and we will make short work,
For, by your leaves, you shall not stay alone
Till Holy Church incorporate two in one.

div.head: Scene 1
div.stage: Enter Mercutio, Benvolio, and their men.

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: I pray thee, good Mercutio, let’s retire.
The day is hot, the Capels are abroad,
And if we meet we shall not ’scape a brawl,
For now, these hot days, is the mad blood stirring.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.p:
Thou art like one of these fellows that, when
he enters the confines of a tavern, claps me his
sword upon the table and says “ God send me no
need of thee” and, by the operation of the second
cup, draws him on the drawer when indeed there is
no need.

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.p: Am I like such a fellow?

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.p:
Come, come, thou art as hot a jack in thy
mood as any in Italy, and as soon moved to be
moody, and as soon moody to be moved.

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.p: And what to?

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.p:
Nay, an there were two such, we should
have none shortly, for one would kill the other.
Thou— why, thou wilt quarrel with a man that
hath a hair more or a hair less in his beard than
thou hast. Thou wilt quarrel with a man for cracking
nuts, having no other reason but because thou
hast hazel eyes. What eye but such an eye would spy
out such a quarrel? Thy head is as full of quarrels as
an egg is full of meat, and yet thy head hath been
beaten as addle as an egg for quarreling. Thou hast
quarreled with a man for coughing in the street
because he hath wakened thy dog that hath lain
asleep in the sun. Didst thou not fall out with a tailor
for wearing his new doublet before Easter? With
another, for tying his new shoes with old ribbon?
And yet thou wilt tutor me from quarreling?

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.p:
An I were so apt to quarrel as thou art, any
man should buy the fee simple of my life for an
hour and a quarter.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.p: The fee simple? O simple!

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.p: By my head, here comes the Capulets.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.p: By my heel, I care not.

sp.speaker: TYBALT
sp.l: Follow me close, for I will speak to them.—
Gentlemen, good e’en. A word with one of you.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.p:
And but one word with one of us? Couple it
with something. Make it a word and a blow.

sp.speaker: TYBALT
sp.p:
You shall find me apt enough to that, sir, an
you will give me occasion.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.p:
Could you not take some occasion without
giving?

sp.speaker: TYBALT
sp.p: Mercutio, thou consortest with Romeo.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.p:
Consort? What, dost thou make us minstrels?
An thou make minstrels of us, look to hear
nothing but discords. Here’s my fiddlestick; here’s
that shall make you dance. Zounds, consort!

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: We talk here in the public haunt of men.
Either withdraw unto some private place,
Or reason coldly of your grievances,
Or else depart. Here all eyes gaze on us.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.l: Men’s eyes were made to look, and let them gaze.
I will not budge for no man’s pleasure, I.

sp.speaker: TYBALT
sp.l: Well, peace be with you, sir. Here comes my man.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.l: But I’ll be hanged, sir, if he wear your livery.
Marry, go before to field, he’ll be your follower.
Your Worship in that sense may call him “ man.”

sp.speaker: TYBALT
sp.l: Romeo, the love I bear thee can afford
No better term than this: thou art a villain.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Tybalt, the reason that I have to love thee
Doth much excuse the appertaining rage
To such a greeting. Villain am I none.
Therefore farewell. I see thou knowest me not.

sp.speaker: TYBALT
sp.l: Boy, this shall not excuse the injuries
That thou hast done me. Therefore turn and draw.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: I do protest I never injured thee
But love thee better than thou canst devise
Till thou shalt know the reason of my love.
And so, good Capulet, which name I tender
As dearly as mine own, be satisfied.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.l: O calm, dishonorable, vile submission!
Alla stoccato carries it away.
Tybalt, you ratcatcher, will you walk?

sp.speaker: TYBALT
sp.p: What wouldst thou have with me?

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.p:
Good king of cats, nothing but one of your
nine lives, that I mean to make bold withal, and, as
you shall use me hereafter, dry-beat the rest of the
eight. Will you pluck your sword out of his pilcher
by the ears? Make haste, lest mine be about your
ears ere it be out.

sp.speaker: TYBALT
sp.p: I am for you.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Gentle Mercutio, put thy rapier up.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.l: Come, sir, your passado.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Draw, Benvolio, beat down their weapons.
Gentlemen, for shame forbear this outrage!
Tybalt! Mercutio! The Prince expressly hath
Forbid this bandying in Verona streets.
Hold, Tybalt! Good Mercutio!

div.stage: Romeo attempts to beat down their rapiers. Tybalt stabs Mercutio.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.p: Away, Tybalt!

div.stage: Tybalt, Petruchio, and their followers exit.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.l: I am hurt.
A plague o’ both houses! I am sped.
Is he gone and hath nothing?

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: What, art thou hurt?

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.l: Ay, ay, a scratch, a scratch. Marry, ’tis enough.
Where is my page?— Go, villain, fetch a surgeon.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Courage, man, the hurt cannot be much.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.p:
No, ’tis not so deep as a well, nor so wide as
a church door, but ’tis enough. ’Twill serve. Ask for
me tomorrow, and you shall find me a grave man. I
am peppered, I warrant, for this world. A plague o’
both your houses! Zounds, a dog, a rat, a mouse, a
cat, to scratch a man to death! A braggart, a rogue, a
villain that fights by the book of arithmetic! Why the
devil came you between us? I was hurt under your
arm.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: I thought all for the best.

sp.speaker: MERCUTIO
sp.l: Help me into some house, Benvolio,
Or I shall faint. A plague o’ both your houses!
They have made worms’ meat of me.
I have it, and soundly, too. Your houses!

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: This gentleman, the Prince’s near ally,
My very friend, hath got this mortal hurt
In my behalf. My reputation stained
With Tybalt’s slander— Tybalt, that an hour
Hath been my cousin! O sweet Juliet,
Thy beauty hath made me effeminate
And in my temper softened valor’s steel.

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: O Romeo, Romeo, brave Mercutio is dead.
That gallant spirit hath aspired the clouds,
Which too untimely here did scorn the earth.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: This day’s black fate on more days doth depend.
This but begins the woe others must end.

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: Here comes the furious Tybalt back again.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: Alive in triumph, and Mercutio slain!
Away to heaven, respective lenity,
And fire-eyed fury be my conduct now.—
Now, Tybalt, take the “ villain” back again
That late thou gavest me, for Mercutio’s soul
Is but a little way above our heads,
Staying for thine to keep him company.
Either thou or I, or both, must go with him.

sp.speaker: TYBALT
sp.l: Thou wretched boy that didst consort him here
Shalt with him hence.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: This shall determine that.

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: Romeo, away, begone!
The citizens are up, and Tybalt slain.
Stand not amazed. The Prince will doom thee death
If thou art taken. Hence, be gone, away.

sp.speaker: ROMEO
sp.l: O, I am Fortune’s fool!

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: Why dost thou stay?

sp.speaker: CITIZEN
sp.l: Which way ran he that killed Mercutio?
Tybalt, that murderer, which way ran he?

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: There lies that Tybalt.

sp.speaker: CITIZEN
sp.l: Up, sir, go with me.
I charge thee in the Prince’s name, obey.

div.stage: Enter Prince, old Montague, Capulet, their Wives and all.

sp.speaker: PRINCE
sp.l: Where are the vile beginners of this fray?

sp.speaker: BENVOLIO
sp.l: O noble prince, I can discover all
